thread.title: Artist re-imagines popular TV show casts as people of color - San Antonio Express-News
thread.title_full: Artist re-imagines popular TV show casts as people of color - San Antonio Express-News

author: Camilo Smith, Houston Chronicle
title: Artist re-imagines popular TV show casts as people of color - San Antonio Express-News
text:
Photo: Julio Salgdo Image 1 of / 20 Caption
Close
Image 1 of 20 Artist Julio Salgado likes to make statements with his art. In this series which has swept the Internet he takes on popular TV shows with all-white casts.
Keep clicking to see the original show and Salgado's "remake". Artist Julio Salgado likes to make statements with his art. In this series which has swept the Internet he takes on popular TV shows with all-white casts.
Keep clicking to see the original show and Salgado's ... more Image 2 of 20 Friends
Friends Photo: Getty Images Image 3 of 20 Salgado describes his show this way: "My version of Friends is set in Oakland. They are mostly college students of color that met at a multicultural center." Salgado describes his show this way: "My version of Friends is set in Oakland. They are mostly college students of color that met at a multicultural center." Photo: Julio Salgdo Image 4 of 20 Full House
Full House Photo: ABC Photo Archives, ABC Via Getty Images Image 5 of 20 "This Full House is a Filipino family and it's set in Daly City, Calif. The oldest daughter is undocumented and the youngest two were born in the U.S. Also, uncle Jesse is queer." "This Full House is a Filipino family and it's set in Daly City, Calif. The oldest daughter is undocumented and the youngest two were born in the U.S. Also, uncle Jesse is queer." Photo: Julio Salgdo Image 6 of 20 Gilmore Girls
Gilmore Girls Photo: Amazon.com Image 7 of 20 "My version of Gilmore Girls is based on my mom and sister. When we first moved to the U.S. and my sister became really ill, my mom gave her one of her kidneys. That's a bond that they will cherish for their rest of their lives," Salgado writes. "My version of Gilmore Girls is based on my mom and sister. When we first moved to the U.S. and my sister became really ill, my mom gave her one of her kidneys. That's a bond that they will cherish for their ... more Image 8 of 20 The Golden Girls
The Golden Girls Photo: NBC, NBC Via Getty Images Image 9 of 20 "This version of Golden Girls is all about social justice and it stars Miss Major Griffin-Gracy, Angela Davis, Dolores Huerta and Grace Lee Boggs...may she rest in power," said Salgado. "This version of Golden Girls is all about social justice and it stars Miss Major Griffin-Gracy, Angela Davis, Dolores Huerta and Grace Lee Boggs...may she rest in power," said Salgado. Photo: Julio Salgdo Image 10 of 20 My So-Called Life
My So-Called Life Photo: Getty Images Image 11 of 20 "Jordan and Angela are two young Muslim teenagers who must deal with love and Islamophobia in the U.S. Wilson Cruz comes back as Rickie," Salgado says. "Jordan and Angela are two young Muslim teenagers who must deal with love and Islamophobia in the U.S. Wilson Cruz comes back as Rickie," Salgado says. Photo: Julio Salgdo Image 12 of 20 Roseanne
Roseanne Photo: ABC Photo Archives, ABC Via Getty Images Image 13 of 20 "This Roseanne is made up of a Mexican family living in Huntington Park, Calif," according to Salgado. "This Roseanne is made up of a Mexican family living in Huntington Park, Calif," according to Salgado. Photo: Julio Salgdo Image 14 of 20 Sex and the City
Sex and the City Photo: Dan Callister, Getty Images Image 15 of 20 Julio Salgado simply says, "These are the Sex and the City girls I'd be friends with!" Julio Salgado simply says, "These are the Sex and the City girls I'd be friends with!" Photo: Julio Salgdo Image 16 of 20 Will & Grace
Will & Grace Photo: NBC, NBC Via Getty Images Image 17 of 20 In this version Salgado says, "Grace is a Korean-American fashion designer living in San Francisco with her best friend Will, a black gay immigration lawyer." In this version Salgado says, "Grace is a Korean-American fashion designer living in San Francisco with her best friend Will, a black gay immigration lawyer." Photo: Julio Salgdo Image 18 of 20 Xena
Xena Photo: Albert L. Ortega, WireImage Image 19 of 20 "Xena and Gabrielle are two Native women who must face off white colonizers," Salgado explains. "Xena and Gabrielle are two Native women who must face off white colonizers," Salgado explains. Photo: Julio Salgdo Image 20 of 20 Artist re-imagines popular TV show casts as people of color 1 / 20 Back to Gallery Julio Salgado describes himself as an undocumented and queer migrant artist. He's from Ensenada, Mexico. "My art deals a lot with these two identities. I try to use humor when dealing with some of these issues."
He's gained a lot of exposure recently because of a series of images he made that look at casts from popular television shows if they were played by minorities. And it took one of the subjects of this art to make the concept go viral.
"Something folks haven't mentioned is the fact that Wilson Cruz, who played Rickie on My So Called Life, was one of the drawings I made, actually shared that image and engaged in conversations via comments," he told La Voz.
His art, which appears on his Facebook page carries this message: "My intention here is to be confrontational and turn popular white characters into POC [people of color] characters."
Click on the link above to check out some of the shows that got the POC treatment from Salgado.
